raw_text:
GE sees 'excellent' world economy
 
 US behemoth General Electric has posted an 18% jump in quarterly sales, and in profits, and declared itself "in great shape".
 
 "We are benefiting from our growth initiatives and an excellent global economy," said GE's chief executive Jeff Immelt. GE is the US' biggest firm based on stock market valuation. GE's net profits were $5.37bn (£2.86bn) for the final three months of 2004, while sales came in at $43.7bn. The group, whose businesses range from jet engines to the NBC television channel, forecast sustained growth at between 10-15% for this year and next. GE's shares rose 1% on the news before ending Friday 0.24% lower.
 
 "The industries GE is in are doing very well. The materials, financial and industrial sectors are all picking up," said Steve Roukis, an analyst at fund manager Matrix Asset Advisors, which has shares in GE. GE said orders in the fourth quarter were 15% higher than in the same period of 2003, "with growth across the board". "In the fourth quarter, nine of our 11 businesses delivered at least double-digit earnings growth," said Mr Immelt. Full year 2004 gains were less spectacular, but still respectable. Net profit was up 6% at $16.6bn. Last year, GE bought Vivendi Universal, merging it with NBC to form NBC Universal. The success of Universal Studio's film 'Ray', a portrait of jazz musician Ray Charles, has helped boost earnings at the unit.
llama3.2:1b: General Electric (GE) reported an 18% jump in quarterly sales and profits, with net profits rising to $5.37bn for Q3 2004. The company declared itself "in great shape" due to its growth initiatives and excellent global economy. GE's stock market valuation makes it the US' biggest firm. The company forecast sustained growth of between 10-15% this year and next, with orders increasing by 15% in the fourth quarter compared to the same period in 2003.
llama3.2:3b: GE posted an 18% jump in quarterly sales and profits, citing an "excellent" global economy as the reason. Net profits were $5.37bn, with forecasted sustained growth of 10-15%. GE's shares rose briefly but ended Friday lower. The company saw a 15% increase in fourth-quarter orders and double-digit earnings growth across nine businesses.
gemma2:2b: General Electric (GE) reported strong quarterly earnings and sales growth, attributing this to an excellent global economy and its own growth initiatives. Profits increased by 18% year-over-year, with sales reaching $43.7 billion. GE expects sustained growth of 10-15% in the coming years.  The company cited strong performance across various sectors, including materials, finance, and industry, as well as strong order increases for the quarter. The acquisition of Vivendi Universal and the success of its film "Ray" contributed to increased earnings for the full year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: GE reports strong quarterly sales and profits, citing global economic growth. The firm sees industry diversification improving its earnings outlook.
qwen2.5:1.5b: GE reports strong sales and profits growth due to improving global economy and successful initiatives. Net profit jumped 18%, with shares rising following its forecast for sustained growth in all businesses across various industries including materials, financials, and industrial sectors. CEO Immelt praised the excellent world economy driving GE's success.
qwen2.5:3b: GE reported an 18% increase in quarterly sales and profits, attributing this to strong growth initiatives and an excellent global economy. CEO Jeff Immelt stated that GE is currently "in great shape". Net profits for the fourth quarter of 2004 were $5.37bn (£2.86bn), with total sales at $43.7bn. GE projects a sustained growth rate between 10-15% for the current and next fiscal years. Analysts note that industries such as materials, financial, and industrial sectors are thriving. Immelt emphasized that nine out of eleven businesses delivered double-digit earnings growth in the fourth quarter. Despite less impressive full year 2004 gains at $16.6bn (up 6% from previous year), GE's purchase of Vivendi Universal and success with 'Ray' film have contributed to boosting unit earnings.

GE's shares rose 1% on the news before ending Friday 0.24% lower.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text. Let me read through the details carefully.

The text starts by mentioning General Electric (GE) is called "excellent" in the world economy. GE is their biggest company based on stock valuation. Their quarterly sales and profits have both jumped by 18%. Jeff Immelt said they benefit from growth initiatives and a good global economy.

Then, GE's net profit was $5.37 billion, with sales at $43.7 billion in 2004. Forecasted growth between 10-15% for next year, but ended up with a smaller percentage increase. They had 20 industries doing well—materials, finance, industry.

Another analyst, Steve Roukis from Matrix Asset Advisors, noted GE's sectors are strong, especially materials and financials. They saw 15% growth in fourth quarter compared to 2003, all businesses had double-digit growth except two. In the full year, their profit went up by 6%, but it wasn't as dramatic. GE bought Vivendi Universal to make NBC Universal, which boosted their film success and earnings.

So I need a concise summary including GE's performance, industries doing well, impacts of their acquisition, and overall economic context.
</think>

GE has shown strong growth in 2004 with an 18% rise in both sales and profits. Their net profit was $5.37 billion and sales at $43.7 billion. GE expects sustained growth between 10-15%. The company is valued on the stock market. GE's industries, such as materials, finance, and industry, are doing well. In the fourth quarter, they saw 15% growth compared to 2003 across all businesses except two, where double-digit earnings were achieved. Overall, their profit rose by 6%. GE purchased Vivendi Universal to expand NBC Universal, which boosted their film success and increased earnings.
tinyllama:1.1b: Despite facing "incredibly difficult macroeconomic conditions" and an improved global economy, General Electric (GE) saw a remarkable jump in quarterly sales and profits, posting $5.37bn net profit for Q4 2004, while also declaring itself in "great shape." Chief executive Jeff Immelts attributed the results to the group's growth initiatives, including an increased focus on sustained growth at a 10-15% level this year and next. The industrial giant recorded $43.7bn net sales for the final three months of 2004, with GE stock ending Friday up slightly by 1%. Analyst Steve Roukias sees GE's success as the result of nine businesses delivering at least double-digit earnings growth in 2004.
tinydolphin:1.1b: GE, the US-based corporation known for its diverse array of globally successful businesses, has reportedly announced that it achieved exceptional results in the fourth quarter of 2004, with record profits and sales growth across various industries. In a recent statement to the stock market, Chief Executive Jeff Immelt disclosed that the company's net profits increased by $5.37 billion or $2.86 billion, reflecting the group's remarkable success in the global economy. GE's performance came amidst robust growth across various sectors, including its materials, financial, and industrial divisions, as well as the delivery of orders from several new projects. This latest achievement is indicative of GE's continued strength in the marketplace and highlights the company's commitment to innovation and high-quality products.
phi:2.7b:
General Electric (GE) reported an 18% increase in quarterly sales and profits, attributed to its growth initiatives and an excellent global economy. Its chief executive, Jeff Immelt, expressed confidence in the company's financial performance and forecasted sustained growth of 10-15%. The stock prices rose on the news, with analysts praising GE's diverse business segments. Despite a slightly lower full year increase, Net profit was still higher than last year, boosted by the success of Universal Studio's film 'Ray'. 
In summary, GE is thriving in an outstanding global economy due to its strategic growth initiatives, with profits and sales figures that indicate sustained growth for the company.

The group's industries are doing well, with nine businesses delivering double-digit earnings growth in the fourth quarter. In 2004, nine of its 11 businesses delivered at least double-digit earnings growth. Overall net profit was up 6% at $16.6bn for the full year.

Sustained growth for this year and next is forecasted at between 10-15%. GE's shares increased by 1% upon the announcement, but ended 0.5% lower. Analysts point to industries like materials, financial, and industrial sectors as doing well. Nine of GE's businesses delivered double-digit earnings growth in the fourth quarter.
granite3.1-dense:2b: General Electric (GE), the US' largest company by stock market valuation, reported an 18% increase in quarterly sales and profits, with net profits reaching $5.37 billion and sales totaling $43.7 billion for Q4 2004. CEO Jeff Immelt attributed this growth to successful initiatives and a robust global economy. GE anticipates sustained yearly growth of 10-15%. Analyst Steve Roukis from Matrix Asset Advisors noted that the company's industrial, materials, and financial sectors are thriving. In Q4, 9 out of GE's 11 businesses reported double-digit earnings growth, with orders up 15% compared to Q4 2003. Full-year 2004 net profits grew by 6%, reaching $16.6 billion. Last year, GE acquired Vivendi Universal and merged it with NBC to form NBC Universal, which benefited from the success of 'Ray', a biographical film about jazz musician Ray Charles.
reference: GE said orders in the fourth quarter were 15% higher than in the same period of 2003, "with growth across the board"."In the fourth quarter, nine of our 11 businesses delivered at least double-digit earnings growth," said Mr Immelt.Last year, GE bought Vivendi Universal, merging it with NBC to form NBC Universal.The materials, financial and industrial sectors are all picking up," said Steve Roukis, an analyst at fund manager Matrix Asset Advisors, which has shares in GE.GE's net profits were $5.37bn (£2.86bn) for the final three months of 2004, while sales came in at $43.7bn."We are benefiting from our growth initiatives and an excellent global economy," said GE's chief executive Jeff Immelt.
